zWlrVzaO9ByVGMF-U225Lw.text: If you guys don't mind my fingers are starting to hurt a little bit, so I am going to keep this as simple as possible.   French toast - get it, without a doubt this was my favorite thing (ask for regular syrup though)  Nutella thing was really good, really rich and definitely could be shared by 2 or more people, another dish I liked.  Besides that, it was your pretty typical breakfast joint, eggs, croissants, biscuits, etc. Nothing that was super memorable. I also do not know how much the final bill was but if I knew... I might dock another star.  THE VERDICT: Once you run out of other breakfast places to go, this is a place worth trying eventually. Do you need to go out of your way? No. But if you are in the aria I highly recommend it.

C-5ASa7X5QsyT_xfV7l0tg.text: With temperatures in Las Vegas now surpassing 100F daily it might seem like Brasserie Fare would be a bit too heavy, but on Saturday, much as they have for over four years, Josh Smith and the team at Bardot again put on a spectacular show complete with old favorites and new plates in tune with the season.  Dining on this day as a party of nine, a range of ages from single digits to senior citizens seated at a long table near the Restaurant's central display of flowers, it was with greetings from familiar staff that the evening started off with a complimentary pour of Bubbles, the 2008 Rose crisp and not too sugary which allowed it to pair nicely with starters including ground to order Tartare and a daily special of Pate en Croute with big flavor inside golden Pastry from Sous Chef Ty Clark.  Not even trying to resist Bardot's city-best Baguette, discs of imported Beurre d'Echire spread liberally over the still-warm center, it was next that a labor intensive Salad of King Crab and Endive competed against two types of Foie Gras for top billing, the Parfait still stunning in terms of texture but "Rossini" even more decadent thanks to braised Beef, Black Truffles and Sauce Bordelaise.  Traveling south for Spanish Octopus with heat and acidity, notes of Saffron perfuming each mouthful, it was not long before old and new ideas arrived on wood, Bardot's infamous Escargot good as ever inside Puff Pastry with plenty of Garlic and Chef Smith's bar menu "Pop Tarte" showing whimsy without compromising the classic combination of Cheese, Onions and Bacon with Bechamel added at the end to resemble "Frosting."   With half of a wood-grilled Lobster rounding out Appetizers, because at Bardot the highlight of many French Restaurants does not need to wait, it was with serviceware reset that Entrees began to arrive steadily, a thick Pork Chop standing up to both Mustard and Horseradish thanks to sourcing and smoking while four plump Scallops from a fleet out of New Jersey shine with natural sweetness amidst a melange of Summer Produce dressed in Brow Butter, Herbs and Sherry.  Never forgetting vertical Macaronis, though this season's Semolina Gnocchi with Tete de Moine, Mushrooms and Squash in two forms is also a meatless show-stopper, those looking for lighter options may also wish to investigate Roasted Organic Chicken served alongside Sauce Vin Jaune or all-new Sea Bass served with crispy Skin, fried Potatoes and a subtle hint of licorice.    Not lacking in accoutrements, the Chicken's cast-iron crock of Bread Pudding and brilliant green Falafel offered with eight Bones of New Zealand Lamb both particularly worth mentioning, it was as Chef Smith carefully carved Beef Wellington tableside that guests delved into Duck Breast brightened by Citrus, though no matter how good the Fowl with crispy Skin there is still no better dish in Sin City than Bardot's Prime Beef protected by Puff Pastry and served with Foie Gras-Madeira Veloute.  Seventeen plates and three sides in at this point, several of the Appetizers additionally ordered double, it was refreshed by Espresso that Dessert came next, a special request for Brunch's French Toast granted and predictably wowing first timers while old favorites such as the signature Chocolate Macaron, Espresso Creme Brulee and "Cheesecake" Mille Feuille rightfully retain their place amidst newer additions such as Strawberry Shortcake Baked Alaska flambeed tableside.   Frequently honored to 'test' new ideas, Chef Smith describing "Gateau Basque Gooey Butter Cake" as the fusion of his Grandmother's all-American recipe with a familiar French classic, it should seem fairly obvious to those familiar that the addition of Cream Cheese and even more Butter to something already rich is over-the-top indulgent, while the Pineapple Tarte Tatin introduced in March remains arguably Bardot's best new dish of 2019 thanks to its diversity of taste, texture and temperature.  FIVE STARS:  Already America's best Bistro or Brasserie, Summer 2019 sees Bardot at Aria continue to evolve by seamlessly integrating classic technique and clever ideas into elegant plates that look and taste as good as what one will find throughout Europe.

XHSOmAuOjYE50nCYeB7dLw.text: Simply spectacular.   We went with a party of eight foodies. Fortunately for me, everyone loved to share and I was able to taste a bit of everything. Each dish I tried was better than the last, from appetizers through dessert.   The French onion soup was a special favorite, and might truly be the best version of this soup I've ever had. Even the broth was scrumptious. But the goblet it comes in is HUGE. Share this one!  The tuna tartare was a pleasant surprise! I'm not usually a fish fan, so I was delighted to find this dish so tasty.   The duck wings with orange sauce are out of this world! Just do yourself a favor and order it, and don't forget to dunk a bite in the yummy hollandaise sauce served in a little orange half. Mmmmm!  The filet mignon was perfection. So tender, so tasty. And the fries served with it (frites) were so rich and delectable -- no doubt thanks to the beef fat they are cooked in.   For dessert, I tried the rum cake and the creme brulee. The rum cake was a bit strong for me, but that creme brulee was fantastic. It hardly lasted a full minute on the table before being gulped up.   This place is superb. Can't wait to come back and try brunch!

5IfVzEi9DLlfNep-ppOsIQ.text: Let's start with the good news: fresh hot crunchy loaves of bagged bread brought to the table, and an impressive selection of craft beers and superb wines! The service is also outstanding!! The selections are wonderful and I highly recommend the beet salad or French onion soup....both of which are quite tasty, although the FO soup could use significantly  less salt. It turned out to be a harbinger of over salted main dishes, including the Pork Chop and Steak Dinners. So salty, in fact, that I would not return. Suggestion/Request: Use little to no salt, and put shakers on the tables for those who need more, and more, and more.

BP8phIG26sq2Z-4KiG5cBA.text: My server Andrea M made my meal even better. Divine French AOC grade butter, foie gras and onion soup with a poached egg. What's not to love?  Very friendly and knowledgeable service. Excellent hand crafted cocktail. Beautiful room. Hurry up and go!

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Check out one of their signature cocktails called and God created woman.

Iigbs5ruusEQzr5cMH07lg.text: EXCEPTIONAL from start to finish this restaurant did not disappoint. Went there for weekend brunch, staff was very friendly and the ambiance is just beautiful. Peach Bellini was perfect, warm baguette with butter to start was delicious. We ordered the Nutella sticky bun which was outstanding and not overly sweet. The roasted hazelnuts on top were a tasty crunch. My wife had steak and eggs and I had the lobster scramble. Both dishes were excellent. I was surprised with the quantify and quality of the lobster - no skimping here. Plus the light touch of caviar on top really set this dish apart. Highly recommend this place! We also ate at another French restaurant (not to be named) but in the vicinity across from the bellagio hotel. It was also very good, but the Bardot is in another league.

Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Nutella sticky bun with roasted hazelnuts.

Tn3Iuij493rZA_k_3beSHA.text: I've been in this industry a long, long time and this is one of the top experiences that I've ever had. Yes the food was phenomenal, the burger was maybe the best in my life, the Best Butter truly lived up to the name, and the Bourguignon was unreal, but these didn't take the experience to the next level. What got me to 5+ stars was Oscar. Hands down one of the best servers that I've ever had. He reminded me of all my favorite people that I've worked with in my career all rolled into one. Friendly, knowledgeable, hilarious, I will be coming back on a regular basis just to see him. Thank you Oscar, see you again soon.

LDNMC7ZwpYBSL9g4UeRngQ.text: What can I say... I am a huge fan! We went for Bastille Day. Great atmosphere! Great food! Don't recommend for a romantic date because it is a bit loud. Great service! Just wish they told us our steak came with fries before we ordered fries as a side. And I am a sucker for a champagne cart!!!

4CaeT5zUgqTGI6jlLRMcQw.text: Bardot is a good restaurant ; what makes it fall just short of being excellent is overall food quality and service. I ordered the fillet mingon steak which was amazing, melting in your mouth tender. My friends ordered the bass which was a bit overcooked and the rack of lamb which was a bit dry. The service also wasn't exceptional for a 5 star restaurant. We were celebrating our friend's 30th and ordered a cake dessert, which they didn't even comp - great restaurants usually do.

Xs-OdLl9NXyhRa_pCNkZ3g.text: Located on the promenade level of the contemporary Aria resort hotel, this newly reimagined french brasserie has all the flair of a casual street side Parisian bistro sans the French accent, of course. I made reservations for weekend brunch and strolled in at about 12:45pm to a fairly full house bustling with a variety of diners sobering up from the previous evening of debauchery I could imagine. The hostess kindly greeted me at the entrance and escorted me to the back of the restaurant where the dining tables were located. From there, I met the server who was agreeably friendly in a casual way and took my orders in a snap.  First to arrive was the king crab crepe served with a bechamel sauce. The crepe was rich, flavorful and it was served perfectly thin and not overly bulky like some crepes I've had the displeasure of experiencing in the past. I would have liked to see more lump crab in the crepe but the amount served was sufficient to maintain the integrity of the dish. The addition of the fried egg made for a beautiful marriage of flavors and textures, which had me savoring each wonderful bite. A great start to my brunch and it whet my appetite for the subsequent dishes on my brunch line up. Next up was the lobster benedict on a light and airy puffed pastry. I was mildly disappointed when I spied what appeared to be langoustines and not lobster tail chunks. It's just a matter of preference l but I feel the lump lobster would have been a more impressive accompaniment to this delightful dish but I'm sure cost played a big role in their decision to use langoustine. All in all, it was a tasty dish and I enjoyed the use of the flakey pastry, which was a refreshing departure from the traditional English muffin. The final dish to adorn our table was the duck confit waffle benedict. Served with a citrusy blood orange maltaise, rustic root vegetable hash and perfectly poached egg, this majestic brunch dish was nothing short of stunning. The duck was warm tender and beautifully balanced in flavor. Usually a confit is typically too salty for me but this preparation was just right. The light and fluffy waffle drizzled with the maltaise sauce and the heavenly poached egg added just the right amount of decadent richness to this praiseworthy dish. #eggporn galore!  Overall, service was agreeable, fairly attentive, and the food was reasonably paced. What Made me a fan was the food! I'd gladly return to enjoy more of that enticing brunch fare when I trek out to SinCity.  Until then... Happyeats!

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Coffee OJ and Baguette
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lobster Benedict
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. King Crab Crepe

Z4YKlPIwmxmgbgNmqVlrWg.text: We went back for a second visit while on property at the urging of a friend from another property.   The hostess staff is amazing! Friendly, attentive and a great start to a fabulous meal.   The venue is stunning. It's has all the making of an amazing space that caters to all aspects of the city.  The service was top flight and attentive. We wanted for nothing.   The number of items on the menu is impressive. The charcuterie is exceptional. The Frisee salad was amazing. We all had steaks and sides. They were cooked perfectly.   They have made some management and staffing changes since my original visit and review. We will definitely be back.

iOjkzWOXJSLIpvTbg3jDeA.text: Service is impeccable. Christina is a consummate professional. I was beyond impressed.   I ordered the gnocchi. The most tender perfect gnocchi. In a sauce that I swear was just butter and cream and garlic. With some kind of mushrooms I've never heard of before and asparagus and toasted hazelnuts and tiny chunks of the world's silkiest Brie that just melted straight into the sauce.   Go to this restaurant.

StUgqG8NT1388iMb_vTN7Q.text: Overall amazing dinner and service.   I would definitely recommend the lamb as well as the lobster bisque!   Will definitely be back on my next trip home o Vegas.

qAvAhwXJ0Tf3mo0CdWJ8tA.text: Best brunch on the strip!!!!  The food was excellent and the service was outstanding.   Ask for Oscars section,  you won't be disappointed. He will help with the best recommendations on food and wine, all while taking great care of you.

fG8pAdKuTnW96Jt8ckiJmg.text: Overall - Bardot Brasserie is a wonderful experience and I recommend dinning at this fine establishment.   Now to the GOOD specifics:  The atmosphere here is lively and fun. It has a great vibe and much energy. Our server, Nelson, was wonderful. He was polite, knowledgeable, and seemed to really care about us. Our main dishes were fantastic. I had the Filet Mignon and my friends both had the Sole Meuniere. They were both top notch. The flavor and quality are worthy of a 5 star rating.   Now the NOT SO GOOD specifics:  We had ordered an $88 bottle of Katheryn Kennedy Cab. from the Sommelier (sorry I don't have his name). As often happens, I expected him to counter with a similar wine up sell. He did that with a much higher end Katheryn Kennedy selling for $700! I understand sales and up selling very well, but that is a huge jump and bad business. Who knows, maybe an up sell of $20-$30 would have worked but if I'm ordering an $88 bottle of wine I can't be up sold for a bottle more than my round trip flight from New York!  As great as the main dishes were, the side dish and dessert were lacking. We shared the side dish of Blistered green beans (lemon butter & almonds). Well they were shockingly tasteless. We also ordered the chocolate macaroon for dessert and it was average at best.   The main dishes, atmosphere and Nelson the server were so good I was thinking 5 stars here most of the evening. I had to take 1 star away for the side dish, dessert and suggestion from the Sommelier.  Hey - 4 stars is fantastic and I will be back next time I'm in Vegas. Maybe Bardot can up sell me to a 5 star rating next time :)

cqqpj6gFI98eIoy93OdKtA.text: Bardot is the place to go for an utterly decadent Vegas brunch! I think it says everything that many of us found ourselves with rose in one hand and a Bloody Mary in the other within 15 minutes of sitting down to eat.  The Nutella cinnamon rolls were one of the best sweet breakfast items I've ever had. The brioche French toast was filthy rich and if you brunch at Bardot without ordering it you're a fool. ;) Lastly, the lobster Benedict is served atop a puff pastry and covered in a beautiful hollandaise.   Needless to say I was overly satisfied after this indulgent meal, but it was worth the inevitable food coma. Head to the pool, get another drink, and keep going - it's Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lobster Benedict.
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Insanely rich and delicious brioche French toast.
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Rosé AND bloody mary&#39;s. Necessary.

BW7sy7TPH-HXqm9_nzEODw.text: Exquisite French cuisine in an intimate setting. Some of the best food I've ever had, as well as great cocktails!

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Flat iron and black truffle fries!

94gn8wYT_a6EmksQHB4wlg.text: Restaurant Week 2016: $50 Prix Fixe Menu - Escargots Bardot: Wild Burgundy snails, toasted hazelnuts, chartreuse garlic butter, puff pastry shells.  - Oak-Smoked Duroc Pork Chop: Bacon lardons, horseradish potato puree, grain mustard beurre blanc - Creme Brulee: Vanilla Bean custard, turbinado croquant  Restaurant Week 2016: $80 Prix Fixe Menu - King Crab Crepe: Buckwheat crepe, black trumpet mushrooms, sunny-side egg, Normandy cider beurre blanc - Maine Lobster Thermidor: Asparagus, fines herbes, mushroom duxelles, sauce bernaise - Chocolate Macaron: French chocolate cookie, Vahlrona chocolate mousse  Everything was delicious. The $80 menu was a lot stronger compared to the $50 menu (or at least our selections) as all three items from the second menu were my favorites of the evening. The King Crab Crepe and Lobster Thermidor were outstanding dishes! If you haven't had this preparation of lobster, you must try it here. It is absolutely delicious. I love many lobster dishes, but this one is on top of the list. Plus, the Chocolate Macaron caught me by surprise. I wasn't really expecting much of it, but the macaron itself had a great consistency and the mousse was lovely. I didn't want it to end!  Though we thoroughly enjoyed our food, service was blah. When we sat down, our server forgot to come to our table (he admitted this), so we waited for quite some time without beverages or menus (even worse for a restaurant with many, many people walking around, including managers). Our server was nice, but he wasn't available very often. He would show up immediately after our food would arrive - basically, when we didn't need anything, but rarely showed otherwise. It was even troublesome to receive water refills. He had a couple tables directly next to us and would literally forget to stop by when checking on them. After we finally got the check, I couldn't flag down a single person to pick up my payment. I was seriously holding up the book with my card sticking out and still, it took several minutes to get anyone's attention. Our overall experience wasn't terrible, but it did leave a bad taste in our mouth and I definitely expect more from a Michael Mina restaurant.  I do wish to try their brunch and am willing to give their service another shot!

TgskFSsnNua7e_wyBG1Gzg.text: Definitely not traditional french. They need to be clear about this being a twist on french type food items with American flavors.  The French onion soup was delicious but the sole was lacking flavor. And don't get me started on our escargot wrapped in puff pastry. All you taste is the pastry no escargot in sight or taste. Birthday dinner wasn't what I thought it was going to be. Came saw and disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

kDerKXo98-8HN-cKVY7BPQ.text: Just amazing food, delicious!  We had the Halibut, Sea Bass and rack  of Lamb .. with some Escargot and beet salad as starters, just amazing !!! 2 thumbs up to chef Michael Mina

PW_k89RbIWTu-NBV4iOiCw.text: Firstly I really like the style of this bistro. It's French retro yet stylish, not pretentious like some of the restaurants in Vegas. I came here for both dinner and brunch. Here are my verdicts: - French onion soup: love the top crust. It's beautifully golden, and when u open it with your fork, u feel the cheese underneath. - prime rib eye: it's good but not the best I had. Perhaps I like it with slightly more fat. - hunter's waffle: interesting twist from classic egg Benedict. They put duck confit in between a waffle and the runny egg. I wish the chef would consider to put some fresh green like lettuce or arugula with this dish to "freshen" up the taste of the whole dish. - escargots: 4 pcs. Thought it would come in 6 pcs as I saw it from other Yelpers' photos. Regardless that, the whole dish is good.   Will come back and try their famous French Toast!!

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Escargot.. Thought it would come with 6 pieces as I saw it on other Yelpers&#39; photos.. What&#39;s going on?
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hunter&#39;s Waffle

SmyalQXLA-uBhp5Qne_YkA.text: We had breakfast here on our last trip and will be having twice on our next trip amazing breakfast amazing service wish they had breakfast every day

ZUBFCrR_4hZgfWdekLbeGQ.text: This afternoon, a close friend and I enjoyed a lovely brunch. The food was great and the service was good. However, one employee went above and beyond the call of duty and I believe needs to be acknowledged. His name is Oscar.   Shortly after receiving our meal, my friend wanted ketchup and orange juice. Our waitress was not around, so we asked another passing by. That waiter agreed to help, but never returned. Oscar passed by and was given the same request. Before he could return, our waitress showed up and we told her of the request believing that the others had relayed the information to her. Shortly there after, the waitress returned without the ketchup proclaiming that the restaurant was "out of orange juice" and that someone was sent downstairs to get more. However, less than 60 seconds later, Oscar arrived with both ketchup and a full glass of fresh OJ. Our waitress never returned to address this issue.   While our waitress did a fine job, in general, it was Oscar who seemed to go above and beyond for a table that was not his responsibility. When leaving, we attempted to give him a separate tip, but he refused. He said that he loved his job and that sometimes it's just good to do the right thing. So, for that, Oscar is to be commended!  Great job and Thank you, Oscar!

YzjmQ1-OkOJmSL2bbyYnGA.text: Wonderful find! The food was creative and absolutely delicious. Service was excellent! A must try! The escargot, hunters waffle and truffle fries were dreamy! Thank you Oscar Alfaro for your recommendations, menu knowledge and wonderful experience.

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

TMwUogiQRGAE0pbNQXqV5Q.text: A pricey but tasty upscale bistro option inside the Aria. The service is appropriately snooty, but the food is pretty good. Mussels came out cold, but were excellent when they came back. The appetizers and even fries were very delicious. The beer menu isn't huge, but the French and Belgian themed list is good for what is there. The wine list is extensive as well. The meat options are excellently cooked and seasoned as you might expect. Be prepared to spend a pretty penny though.

5BMCcSe5GwQVH8WnidAeGg.text: Ate lunch on a weekday afternoon.  No people.  Was empty.  Had the fixed price lunch.  Wasn't worth it.  The deserts were awful soup was fairly good.  Fish dish was good.  Sandwiches were very plain.  Got oysters.  No explanation of what they were or from.  Our server was more interested in setting up for dinner.   Not worth 200 plus for lunch.

LqTH2mJug-md6bXkoKEelA.text: I'm a huge Chef Michael Mina fan and so naturally was excited to try this one. We arrived late, an hour before closing so sat at the bar whole waiting for a table without reservations.  They had just began happy hour so instead of $26 glass of pinot noir,received a glass of Acacia pinot  for only $8. Score! The restaurant was about 1/4 filled but it was a 10 minute wait to set the table...not sure why son e the tables were already all set.   Service was mediocre,our server took about 10 more minutes to get us waters which was heavily chlorinated. In a restaurant where you serve good food, maybe invest in a ro system for water?  We ordered 4 courses of appetizers :  1) escargot- too buttery ,nauseatingly rich because the butter was trapped within the pastry 2) king crab crepe- light texture but also too heavy on butter,trumpet mushrooms were a nice touch 3) foie gras parfait- light, fluffy and melted perfectly  4)prime beef tartare- delicious!! Egg yolk mixed in with grade A beef ,perfect   Our friends ordered the 4 course summer prefixe meal and it looked like a great deal.    Overall if they lightened up on the butter, I would've given more stars.

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

fErdR2xzWENQ4I-xVdrqOw.text: Loved the feel of this restaurant.  Mom, brother, hubby and I came here for dinner one of the nights we were in Vegas, on advice from the chef at Other Mama.  Thankfully, reservations were not hard to make.  If you're familiar with Balthazar in NY, it reminded me very much of that restaurant.  It was busy/buzzing but not pretentious or snobby.  Our server was a rarity - a handsome, 50-something, funny/flirty French guy.  I wish we had him at all the French restaurants we've been to.  Even mom couldn't get over his looks lol.  Between him and the helpers, we wanted for nothing the entire evening. (Although he did try to make me feel bad about getting tap water for the table when I ordered sparkling for myself.)  To start, we went with the special bread and butter to which our server said he wanted our opinion on how it compared to the regular bread service.  The fancy butter was definitely more flavorful.  But both were delicious and we ate a buttload.  We also ordered the beef tartare and foie gras parfait.  Both also very delicious.  I'm a huge fan of both dishes in general and Bardot does them well.  We sure did layer on that foie gras parfait very thickly...yum!  Mom got the French onion soup and she loved it.  She shared a little but otherwise, went to town on the pastry crust and soup.  To be honest, at this point, we were feeling really full already (especially mom) but we still hand our entrees coming.  Mom and hubby both got the 14oz ribeye with fries.  I got the duroc pork chop to be different.  Mom's ribeye was pure decadence.  So much marbling and so well cooked to the medium rare we asked for.  Wow.  My pork chop was also very delicious though I should have gone with my instincts and asked for it to be done at medium instead of well done.  We were so stuff we had to skip dessert.  Our server understood completely.    Fantastic dinner, pristine service and wonderful time had by all.  Love it!

G7cO4v4ckG-W6TCpS7k9tg.text: Excellent lunch dining experience at Bardot. Raul, our server was very attentive. Excellent food and excellent server and no wait time is the best recipe for an excellent dining experience. Must try: escargot with puff pastry, hunter's waffles, Maine lobster Benedict. The French toast is quite humongous; unless you have a bottomless stomach, don't attempt it so that you may save some space for their dessert.  Michael Mina, if you are reading this, please open one (Bardot) in San Francisco! Pleaseeee! :)

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Escargot with puff pastry
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

r0ptjgpsziM7j1e359HZTw.text: Just to be clear, the 2-star rating is associated to two separate visits to Bardot. The first time I dined at this restaurant was a 4 only due to long wait to order our first drinks. However, today, I would say it's more like a 1 star-rating. Although our waitress was very nice, she was nowhere to be found. We ordered our appetizer fairly quickly but waited about 30-40 minutes for it to come out. Our order for our entrees were taken after about 30 minutes of looking around for our waitress. We seemed to not be the only ones in search of her. Since we were already frustrated about the wait, my boyfriend cancelled the rest of our order and we left. The manager ended up comping our coffee and appetizer which was nice, but I would have rather paid for a nice meal and a good experience. My boyfriend tipped the waitress $20 anyway, so she made out either way!   I love the Hunter's waffle and the foie gras parfait, but I think it'll be a while before I decide to return to Bardot.

ALfPBmfy6qp9MhsvAGsXtg.text: Good service great wine by the glass list and most amazing chocolate macaroon dessert I ever had in my life. I have to say though the moules frites are so much better at Bouchon. But the beet salad and pork chops were phenomenal. I got dessert to go and they glued the pastry down in the box with chocolate sauce so that it did not slide around which was such a nice touch.

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

X6OR5Kl3z5VsgjKjOFUzYg.text: This was an amazing dinner!! I loved everything about it. Service was great, the restaurant is beautiful, the drinks were yummy, and my food just exquisite.  The recommended drink with the signature "B" is called "And God created woman" it's gin based and has a flowery delicate taste. It was a well made drink, all of the components blended so well...I was in love! It's a good time to tell you I am not a gin drinker but even I recommend it. Next was our meals. I don't have a single bad thing to say. Everything was just so damn good. Our warm asparagus salad was a perfect starter. It was so simple but tasted like it was a complicated dish. Asparagus, prosciutto, egg, hollandaise, and black truffle. Delicious.  Next was my pork chop. It was melt-in-my-mouth delicious and it was Huge! It was so smokey and so tender. Yum yum! The mustard sauce on the side was a perfect companion to it too . Not overly mustardy. I'm not a big fan of mustard usually but I liked it!  I'd say this dinner was a great one. Loved everything about and I would recommend having dinner here.., check it out!

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beautiful bar
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dining room
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Special of the night.... Warm asparagus salad with shaved black  truffles

p4GHv9cocvENoIUsINM5_g.text: A truly terrific restaurant. Exceeded our expectations. Phenomenal food and service. Cannot recommend enough.

IyMnvtlWuQrtxbBUXKBcDg.text: A lot of French people were real deal eating here on Christmas morning. What does that tell you? If I go to a Chinese restaurant and see a bunch of old Asians eating there, I know the place is legit. Well, so is BARDOT Brasserie! Plus, you know Las Vegas has become a culinary destination when French people both work and vacation there. I was kinda surprised.  We had perfect Micheladas and split Lobster Benedict with a generous serving of Maine lobster on croissants smothered in what they called a sauce Bernaise, but it had a delicious pinch of nutmeg in it that suited the shellfish. Newburgh? We also had a frisee aux lardons salad. Otherwise the eggs came with no sides. It's a dish best split like we did, like vol au vent with bacon and salad. Exactly what you want for Christmas brunch. Skip the buffets and still get the good stuff.  Oh, and it really is The Best Butter in the World. It came with a warm demi baguette in a paper bag.

3E3ZHgTaRbl8sYjdQtu11g.text: Amazing food, amazing service.  Nate, the manager, care about the good service and experience.  I ordered the sweet breads, which were moist and tender, turnips were perfectly roasted.  I'm giving them 4 stars because I disagree with the chefs interpretation of escargots, very flavorful but on the dry side.  I learned to eat escargot in Zurich and Paris.

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7HKi9ff55KSmzO3Ko7SEvA.text: Came here last night for the first dinner of my brother in law's 40th birthday celebrations.   Beautiful interior, polite and efficient service - fking horrible food.   My flat iron steak was THE saltiest piece of meat I've ever had in my life. I only ate half because I was starving. My wife tried a piece and could not believe I had eaten so much.   My sister in law didn't finish her rib eye for similar reasons and she's an Argentinian carnivore.   The steak tartare was probably the only decent dish.   If you feel like spending $300-400 on a completely subprime experience around your red meats, this is the place for you!  Our blonde server was nice and comped us a couple of desserts upon feedback of the main meal, but it really doesn't make up for paying $49-70 for disappointing steak dishes. I could have gone to SW or Prime for that pricing.

A7TD9G1MtCDSdVvgoQ89NA.text: I absolutely adore Bardot Brasserie and have been for dinner, brunch, and happy hour.  First the decor and atmosphere are really lovely, walking that fine line between relaxed and upscale.  My absolute favorite item to order here is the steak tartate.  It's packed with flavor and served with salty thin chips that are a perfect compliment.  At brunch they have multiple eggs benedicts that are all served on these perfectly crunchy but pillowy croissants.  The oysters are fresh and phenomenal. They also have everlasting rose in both sparkling and regular that is a fun joy to add to the experience.  The service is always spectacular as well - friendly and prompt.  I highly recommend visiting Bardot when in Vegas at the Aria.

ZWq1eNjWgcqZVrFwoyPAAg.text: French Toast, Nutella sticky bun, cold brew and rose; not your typical paring, but it works. If you have a sweet tooth, stop by BARDOT. The ambiance is pleasing to the eye as well. Shout out to Raymond for being so welcoming and taking care of us. We will for sure be back to try the Beef Wellington.

9erj_CMfDb8VJI_-3xZ-aA.text: When we want brunch on the strip at a decent price with impeccable service, we do BARDOT! Eric the bartender is one of the most genuine severs in the business. The French twist and ambiance is charming, and the place is peppered with fresh pink roses, a favorite of mine! Rose all day for a flat fee is a perk too. In the mood for a burger, they've got you covered. Want homemade quiche? Look no further. The salmon platter has the cutest loaf of bread and the accompaniments are on point. We've had the French toast to start as you could share with an army. Don't forget to try the syrup!  See you soon, Eric!

b4wtGNvW9kkD4gCZ_mEEQQ.text: I like this restaurant. The steak with super fins is very juicy. I definitely recommend them. The service was very quick and attentive.

iKIJXtcPjMnn4hu_XY3U9A.text: This place will not disappoint.  Many chef inspired dishes, and appetizers on the menu.  I had the grass fed Neu York strip.  It was cooked to perfection.  I choose the peppercorn sauce, and it was a nice addition, but not needed.  I went with the Mac and Cheese, that is a large portion, but really could be eaten by a single person.  I have no idea how they get every macaroni to stand on edge!  It's a neat presentation, and tastes fantastic.  Insider tip: sub the potato puree for the fries.  The fries are good, but you can get good fries anywhere.

_7E7VUosVryj29yGr5zWOg.text: They lost my credit card and then charged me for someone else's food and didn't do anything to remedy the situation. They made me 1 hour late to my concert.

sl9GuHXeFtiRRIlHUBAmGg.text: I decided to take my girlfriend out on a nice date through Las Vegas and I decided to start the night here. It was recommended through a colleague and boy was it a great decision. Environment is right and the food is beyond sensational. Steak tartare was probably my favorite dish accompanied with some artisanal potato chips. Because it is a Brasserie, my girlfriend and I both got steaks that were cooked to perfection!   The service went above what I expected. Friendly, patient, and took the time to talk with us and about food outside of the restaurant.  Going to make reservations very soon because I'm going back

Wo3u1GCFgadk2uOk4dY3Og.text: Had a dinner meeting here with my amazing team from work! The food and service was great! It is on the pricey side of things but the service and quality of food made it worth it. We had the bone marrow which melted off the spoon as well as the ribeye which was delicious. I recommend it for a group setting as well as a intimate date.

zXqTMTth_QaUIjaZ9IOZ_A.text: Best dinner my girlfriend and I had! The bone marrow, Le Fromage, and the King crab crepe are to die for! My mouth gets watery every time I think about it! Our server Oscar took care of us very well. It was my girlfriends birthday and Oscar poured us a complimentary sparkling champagne.

AB06a5K-8NvwrWIsNjOCcg.text: It took me forever to find this place, but I was happy when I finally did. In addition to the complimentary bread, I happened to get bread with both courses. As the French are known for their bread, no objections here!  I started with the Foie Gras Parfait. I found there to be too much ruby port gelee, which drowned out some of the delicious foie gras, but you can scrape some off and put it to the side. The Mussels Marinieres were fantastic with a generous portion of mussels and a delectable butter/vermouth/tarragon broth.

w0yKzYlAwV0K_P38C3SzTg.text: This is for the Happy Hour, and what a good Happy Hour it was.  I had decided to try the HH for my birthday and at the last minute invited a couple of friends as well.  We sat at the bar (hooks below the bar to hang your coat/purse) and had to wait a little before we could order since they start the HH exactly at 5pm and not a minute before.  The bartender was really good about letting my friend sample the different beers and cider on tap and we all wound up with the Ommegang Witte to start while waiting for 5pm.    Once we were able we ordered the duck wings, shrimp cocktail, bone marrow, fries, both tartes, and the macaroni au gratin to share.  The wings were a big hit and we wound up ordering more of those.  The tartes were also great; so simple but so delicious.  Neither of my friends wanted to try the bone marrow but that was alright because it was wonderful and I was happy to have its deliciousness all to myself.  The drink of the day was the Bee's Knees made with gin, honey syrup, and lemon and it also was delicious.  You may see a theme here.  The fries, macaroni, and shrimp cocktail were all good but nothing out of the ordinary taste wise.  The garlic mayo with the fries was really good, though.   Our bartender was friendly and the food came in good time frame.  We left full and little tipsy before 7pm and the bar was pretty full with the restaurant starting to get busy on this Saturday night.  Based on the Happy Hour, I definitely want to come down and give the regular menu a try.

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Nice little alcove at the restrooms.
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. No paper towels in this restroom!
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp cocktail &amp; tarte.

Dt6oYvXusXo7PIwmoEZJaw.text: The duck breast was tender and lean.  The portion size was more than plentiful.  The bone marrow was oh so tasteful and needed more bread to finish its buttery goodness.  My coworkers were all pleased with their orders: pork chop, filet mignon, gnocchi, lobster bisque, and the onion soup.  We all struggled to finish our entrees, too good to leave them unfinished.  I will be back to try the other items like the duck wings a l'orange and the rack of lamb.

DKq_11FFm_PcJA8URiKtlA.text: The overall experience here was terrible, not because the food was horrible but that the service was atrocious.  Our waiter, Oscar, thought he was in France and was giving attitude like he was a Frenchman to an American tourist.  First off, Oscar just had mad attitude taking our order.  When we didn't order alcoholic drinks nor appetizers, he got all pissy.  We had a nice dinner planned at e by Jose Andres (that's a place you should def check out). that night so we wanted a light lunch.  Plus not everyone in Vegas is a degenerate that drinks and gambles at all hours...so what if we didn't order drinks.  When it's my turn to order, I see they have a french dip, which I usually really like.  I turn to him and start to order but I noted that the french dip is a chicken french dip.  I tell him to cross that off since it's not a traditional beef french dip.  He rolls his eyes impatiently.  I quickly switch my order to the French onion soup but I asked him about the option to add short rib, black truffle & a poached egg.  He says its a completely different soup.  So I ask his opinion about the soup and whether or not he likes it.  He replies "if you need to ask its not for you" and he just walks away.  WTF?!?!?!  Seriously?  He is in the service business and if he can't provide customer service go do something else.  Have you ever had a waiter just walk away from you in the middle of a discussion?  The food itself was average at best.  The pastry basket was bad as most of the pastries didn't look or taste fresh.  Do yourself a favor and go to Bouchon in the Venetian for pastries.  We just returned from SF were we had awesome KA's at b. patisserie and we also recently tried Dominique Ansel's new bakery in LA where he had the DKA's (his spin).   All of these places blow the pastry basket at Bardot out of the water.  I can't believe they even sell this stuff here.  A couple of us got the French onion soup, which wasn't bad but pretty average.  At least it wasn't overly salty like bad French onion soup.  My wife ordered the burger.  When it arrived it looked like a pretty average burger but she said it was awesome.  So of course I took a bite and I have to admit looks can be deceiving.  It was pretty damn good (and for $20+ it better be).  The meat, caramelized onions, and bread all went really well together.  Easily the best thing we ate there.  But I wouldn't go again for the burger (since the best of the food was average or below par at best) and the service probably one of the worst we've ever experienced (Recommendation to Oscar: if you want to be a waiter do it properly otherwise go do something else).  It's unfortunately because we were just in SF and had dinner at Michael Mina's flagship restaurant (named after himself) and it was an awesome experience from the service level to the food.  If only a small portion of that restaurant rubbed off on Bardot, the experience here would be significantly better.

6Bzn6HTE_4xIJptX2fn4hA.text: Beautiful restaurant and good happy hour but the rest was a disappointment. Skip the $5 butter. Was good but not great.  Just a way to get you to pay extra for bread and butter. I had the beet salad. Was just okay. My husband had the pork chop and was not impressed.  Service was poor.  Our waiter good barely pay attention to us long enough for taking our order.  We were asked when making our reservation if we were celebrating anything. Said it was our Anniversary.  Was never acknowledged by anyone.  Lots of outstanding places to eat in Vegas. Stop here for happy hour and move on.

YEjdHd4pLUTSU9266dNweQ.text: What a pretty place. Fits Aria perfectly. Take the escalators upstairs, by the buffet. Party of 7 last night. Great hostess was quick to get us situated. Our servers were attentive and always filling our water glasses. Never rushed us even when we stayed an extra hour after our dinner was done. Filled our coffee cups twice. Didn't have an attitude when we each paid with credit cards. Food was beautifully presented. We ordered tons of appetizers and the 20 ounce steak to share. Two dozen oysters, foie gras served on a bed of lentils, King crab crepe, bone marrow, escargot on puff pastry(YUM), tuna tartare with quail egg, duck wings, side order of green beans and French onion soup. Super good. Dessert: cherry clafouti and Mille feuille

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

-XvUnpHniPSrzRX-zPqtlg.text: Party of 6 celebrating a birthday - I have to say that I have a hard time understanding the 5 star reviews for this place.  I would give this place a solid "meh." With the high cost for a meal here comes the burden of expectation, and the group of us walked out thinking that the food was thoroughly mediocre overall, which is really what drove the rating down.  For easy reading, let me go point by point. Service - Service was excellent, an easy 5 star rating here.  Servers were friendly, attentive, and were understanding when we sent a cocktail back that we didnt care for. Atmosphere - Similarly excellent - 5 stars here again. Food - Here is where things start to go off the rails a bit.  To be clear, I'm not at all saying that anything we ate here was horrible/inedible.  Food simply didn't come close to expectations. Starters -  Starters were really the strong part of the mea. Endive Salad - 4 stars, not much to say here.  Fine, but otherwise unremarkable. Lobster Bisque - 5 stars. This has the distinction of being the best food items.  Super creamy and rich, the soup was excellent. Only 5 star rating we can give. Onion Soup -  4 stars, the soup was a little on the salty side, but was otherwise pretty good. Meals - And here comes the heart of it. Parisian Gnocchi - 3.5 stars - Two people at the table ordered this, and both came away with the same complaints - first, the gnocchi was not served hot, and second, there wasn't anything particularly remarkable about the flavor or presentation. Duck Breast - 2 stars - Real problems here.  First, and most importantly, the duck was significantly overcooked and underseasoned.  The breast was very rubbery/chewy and had cooled significantly at the time of serving, though several of us commented that the huckleberry jus was a nice touch.  Certainly can see how this dish could have been a real winner under different circumstances, but that was not our experience. Rack of Lamb - [my dish]3 stars - the good part - the lamb was cooked to an absolutely perfect medium rare, really nailed that part.  The problem was that it was severely under-seasoned, which is really a shame.  If properly seasoned, a little over/under on the cook would have been forgivable.  The veg and polenta were serviceable.  Overally, same thought as the previous - this could have been a home run under different circumstances. Really wish this had been a better experience - they do make really good cocktails, despite the comment about sending one back.  That was just a personal taste issue.   Highly unlikely to give this place another shot.

3qCxKxTXo1vVUqOqGoiFKQ.text: I just ate at the bar and holy crap!!! The food was slamming, Ribeye and Pork Chop. Even better than the food was the service. Michelle, Brooke, and Alex added a personal touch not often found in this town. Sit, eat, and enjoy. You won't be disappointed.

JoklPASIjFL1usorRq2wCg.text: We went for brunch and I must say that my wife and I agree that this was the best meal we have ever had in Las Vegas.  We always eat family style, sharing dishes so we dan try more things. We started with the perfect tiny little escargo in puff pastry. I swear my wife could have died and gone yo heaven right then and there, except we were enjoing endless sparking French Rose wine way too much.  So we went on to the amaing buckwheat crepe with crab, and the one of a kind hunters waffle with duck confit and a sauce I cannot even describe it was so sumptious.  We also indulged, for $5, in the best French butter we have ever enjoyed, on crispy french baggette with sea salt we sprinkled on the buttered bread. OMG,  Perfect service, perfect food. Like everything in Vegas, it was an expensive brunch, but one we will never ever forget. We will return for dinner for certain.

nJZj02hYs2P98lcPi9JWEw.text: I came here for my Birthday and was quite disappointed. I've honestly had better food for the amount I'm paying.  First off, the food was just okay. We started off ordering the King crab crepe and foie gras parfait for the appetizers. The king crab crepe was just so so.. flavor or texture did not impress me at all. The foie gras parfait spread was nice and creamy but the toast that came along with it was too thick and it made the whole appetizer unbalanced.  Starting with entrees, we ordered the heritage chicken roti and the loup de mer. The word for both of those dishes are bland and boring. Me and my best friend couldn't even finish our food.. and we usually finish our food!  So 2 star rating is for the service. Food gets 0.  Although food was not that great, I will come back and try the brunch menu. Hopefully, it will be a completely different experience.

lhxgQrCC5AxOhsY2CGO3TQ.text: Continuing our endless mission of finding cheese and charcuterie plates, we ended up at Bardot for a nice dinner.   From the start, the service was prompt, courteous, and friendly. Our server helped us narrow down our cheese selection and the sommelier was very knowledgeable. We live in wine country and wanted to venture out from the familiar California wines of Napa and Sonoma. We were looking for something oaky, buttery, and smooth...with a twist. The sommelier guided us to a nice bottle of 2012 Louis Jadot Meursault, a Chardonnay.   The wine was just what we were looking for.  It had a smooth buttery taste with a touch oak and a hint of mouthfeel.    Our cheese and charcuterie plates were excellent. The cheese selections were a tad small, but they tasted great.    The charcuterie plate was sized well and in both cases, the accompaniments provided fun additional flavors.   Our main dishes were a major let down. We had the salmon with lentils and gnocchi. The fish was cooked well, flakey with crispy skin, but was a touch heavy on the salt.  The lentils were too salty to eat. I liked the flavor profile they were going for but after two bites and a bitter face, I was done.   The gnocchi was also too salty.  Parmesan dishes are usually salty, but this was over the edge. On the plus side, the gnocchi was very tender. The asparagus was woody and stringy.   I debated to give this restaurant 3 or 4 stars.  The main dishes were some of the worst I've had at any of the nicer restaurants in Vegas, but the service was excellent and our appetizers were really good.  I would like to hope that my experience was an off night for the chef.  I decided on 3 because the main course should be the highlight of a meal, not the appetizer.

-nj6AZ4t6l40mA7nxwb1eQ.text: Delicious dinner! The space is gorgeous, like a regular French bistro sexified and given the nightclub treatment. Service was attentive and good. The steak tartare is incredible! Get it! The foi grois w fruit was good, very smooth. The duck wings were meh. The bread is very delicious, hard not to fill up on it. The pork chop was so tasty, the veggies complimented it very well. The steak is also top drawer. I liked the cocktails and thought the apple one went very well w the porkchop.

PDdycRhkpOrLwyLNM9zlJg.text: Brunch here was fantastic! A True French bistro that exceeded our expectations. Delicious foie gras to start on homemade bread.  We also ordered the burger which was amazing flavor. Probably one of the best burgers I've ever had. Our server explained the process of them grinding to different types of meat together. Quite delicious without being overfilled from the bun. Of course paired with perfect fries that was so light and airy.  Their ham Benedict on croissants was a nice change to the traditional Benedict. Great sized portions to share.  Service was excellent, would highly recommend!

w5tTIoiN5vP4CbEay6Dc5A.text: I expected nothing less than excellent food and service and Bardot Brasserie didn't disappoint. My friend made reservations about a month before since it can get pretty busy on weekends. They have an extensive wine list and let us try a sample before we made our selection. We decided on wonderful Vouvray. Service was impeccable. Our server was attentive but not overbearing.    For appetizers I tried the escargot which was different then how it's traditionally prepared. There are 6 that come on a wood plank served in a puff pastry topped with a pesto sauce. It was very flavorful. My date got the foie gras which was accompanied by a thick, crusty bread. Very tasty! For our main entrees we tried the lamb chops which were cooked and seasoned perfectly. We skipped on the coffee and dessert (although the creme brulee was tempting) as we were both full. Wonderful experience from start to finish!

Vqxdh2IwLQTRTdeUxcgbTA.text: I've been here 3x so far and can't go wrong with French food! I was super impressed my first time dining in, food was wonderful, service was superb, however my most recent visit in, the server forgot our drink orders for half the table and was difficult to find/flag down for additional service/help. Especially now with having to pay for parking to dine here, I'm really counting on an excellent service/meal but coughing up $200 for a family meal for mediocre service is pretty annoying and overshadows the good food.

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Brunch menu mussels
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Steak &amp; eggs plus a side of hash browns we had ordered separately
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kale &amp; bacon quiche

GmQd0r1p3CzHKNCC5gfo6Q.text: My experience started out rough because of the service. My server was abrupt and impatient. I'm not sure if he heard me complain, but I noticed some improvement when he came back. I thought he was racist because I noticed how charming he was with the Caucasians at the next table. It's interesting that his recommendation changed from person to person. My friends who got there earlier asked for recommendations and he told them to get a set of items. Then when I asked, he told me another set of items. I was at a French brasserie, so I had felt like I had to get the escargot. Not escargot in butter, but this puffed pastry escargot. Next he mentioned the lobster roll was unlike any other and I can't find it anywhere. He also recommended the Hunter's waffle. I wanted one croissant for $3 and he told me I might as well get the "bread basket" for $10. I ordered pastis and the server had no idea what I was talking about. I told him, that this is a French restaurant and you must have Ricard at the bar. He checked and they brought me a glass of pastis on the rocks for $15. At that price, I should have instead ordered the $20 bottomless brunch rose. Everything I ordered was excellent. My favorite was the bread basket, which is more of heaven in a basket. My first attack was the canele. I wasn't going to share that with anyone. I inhaled it. Next was the croissant which was crisp just like I've had in France. Then there was a kouign-amann and raisin pastry which I shared with my table. This is a Michael Mina restaurant which I've had on my list of places to eat at Vegas and I'm glad I was able to check it out during this trip. Chef Joshua Smith is the chef de cuisine and is taking French classics to another level of refinement. The management needs to better train the staff. I didn't feel the service level matched the restaurant quality. It did improve towards the end of my meal, but was not at all memorable. The food outshined the service. 3 stars service. 5 stars for the elevated take on French classics. About the chef - michaelmina.net/restaura... Chef Joshua Smith on Munchies - munchies.vice.com/videos...

Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Canele

PsiHwlgcaX1lYYdgoOvoAQ.text: This should have been a much better experience then it was.   We were a party of 3 and went yesterday on a Saturday.  Since were were going to a show that night we opted to have a larger lunch so we would not be rushed at a restaurant trying to get to the theater on time.  I made a reservation for 1:30.  When our server came to the table with the menus she informed us that the kitchen closes at 1:30 and that we needed to get our orders in.  We started by splitting an order of steak tartare which was great.  But then my beet salad, which was to me my first course, showed up at the same time as my steak burger.  I think in America's would just call this a hamburger, I was expecting this to be more of a piece of steak in a roll.  I was unhappy that the kitchen slammed out all of our food at once so that they could close.  I discussed this with our server who told me she had no control over the kitchen so she sent the manager out to the table.  I ended up refusing the burger we finished, paid and left very unsatisfied.    Don't take a reservation at 1:30 when your intention is to close the kitchen at the same time.  If I knew this was the restaurant policy I would have made a reservation earlier.  If a restaurant seats a guest then the kitchen needs to be available while that guest is having their meal.  Otherwise how different is this from fast food which is the opposite of French cuisine.

Aa4Qu6WaXMViSsgYVcB9JQ.text: Amazing seafood, prepared to perfection.  Also had the colossal sized chocolate macaron, delicious.  Bathrooms felt like I was in a 5 diamond men's club.

n-eRRDgR9U8_0eyUblDRqA.text: Amazing food, service and ambiance. I absolutely loved my experience here. My fav diah was the foie gras was paired perfectly with this delish jam and toasty bread. I can't wait to go back for round 2!

6ipLXOs70nFDZwyPn8O2mw.text: My first dinner few months ago at Bardot was excellent. I went back with some friends and was disappointed. All the dishes were too salty. The duck breast had good flavor but was tough. Could be over cooked or too lean. The sea bass was just too salty and texture was not good; Chilean sea bass would be better. The lobster was disappointing too. The only dish that I enjoyed was the scallops. I gave it 2 stars cos service was very good. Bread and desserts were enjoyable.

QvZx-s40gcRXnmExwWTMnw.text: Located in the Aria, this upscale restaurant has some really great food, a gorgeous ambiance, and really slow service.   This is a pricy option for a late dinner in the Aria area without having to eat at the Aria cafe (slightly less slow) downstairs. However, despite the slow service we received on the Thursday night before EDC, the food and dranks really wow'd us. My fiance started the evening with a drink I've only been able to jot down as the "Blood and Sand Scotch drink". It was orangey and smooth and finished in a few minutes.   The beef tartare was a delicious starter. The chips that came with it were super yummy and I was a bit sad we didn't ask for more chips. No matter. I had the pork chop for dinner which was smokey and thick and a lot of meat to put in my mouth. The horseradish mashed potatoes that came with my dish was buttery and creamy and soooo good. My fiance had the flat iron steak which also had a smokiness to it and was nice and tender.   For a not very busy part of the night, it was difficult flagging down a server for water and drank refills, so I think the wait staff could put in a little more effort in being attentive. However, the servers (especially the one who recommended dranks) were very friendly when they were able to stop by. Definitely on the pricy side, so I'm not sure when I'll come back. Maybe when I win the jackpot on the Willy Wonka slot machine.

photos.caption: Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork chop with horseradish mashed potatoes. Smokey and thick and them potatoes is buttery and creamy!
Photo of BARDOT Brasserie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef tartare. Yummy!

5_aMoeNHqe7P4E6jG_ZGJw.text: One of higher priced and higher-end restaurants where we'd expect high quality food and service, but haven't found it. 1. Small table squeezed between other seated tables in small area of the room, while half the room was empty until we left. I think they could've at least spread the customers/parties farther away from each other until more customers arrive. I saw another customer complaining about the same issue in a previous Yelp review, but looks like this restaurant doesn't learn or doesn't care much about customer experience. The table also felt too small for 4 people. 2. Very long wait for the soup before the entree and no waitress around, until we had to ask the water server if we could get the soup soon. 3. I ordered medium-rare wagyu steak, but gotten one of the rarest/uncooked steaks I've ever eaten. I felt like I'm eating raw cow. Also, I didn't see much marbling in the meat, associated with wagyu beef. Although there was some nice crust on the outside that tasted really good, and whatever I could eat was good. I could only imagine that the steak could be really good if cooked a little better. 4. The waitress recommended mac-n-cheese as a side dish, which looked interesting, but tasted ordinary and somewhat too cheesy. At least they should've recommend a better side dish, unless they don't serve anything better... 5. The waitress asked if we like the food and need anything before we started eating, but later never came back to follow up when we actually needed her. We haven't seen her again until finishing the meal. Although this could be the restaurant's fault, as the waitress seemed to be serving a lot of tables, possibly around 10. Although it shouldn't take too much time for her to ask couple more times if we need anything else. 6. The waitress looked and acted like someone who should be cleaning tables at a buffet, without even basic education or food serving skills. She made the whole place feel like a low end country diner. Do they just hire anyone from the street to wait tables here? 7. Overall the rest of the food was good, but the sides somewhat ordinary. Ordinary fries, ordinary tasting mac-n-cheese, ordinary onion soup, undercooked steak. We wanted to be just a little impressed with something. 8. We waited long time for a dessert menu, after finishing the food. It was so long that we've decided to go somewhere else for dessert. While every restaurant should know that the most important time to serve customers is when they arrive, and when they are finishing eating. How can you even run a restaurant not understanding such basics, or not training your staff? 9. A manager came to check on us when finishing our dinner, but it was too late to complain about food, while it didn't feel appropriate to ask him for dessert menu. I also wanted to gather my thoughts to write some notes for this review. Though maybe we should've talked to him. 10. Our bill was $280 and felt overpriced considering the above (we didn't order drinks except couple bottles of water).  We were initially excited and looking forward to visiting this place, but left quite disappointed. We are a family of 4 and initially each of us rated the place between 2 and 4, but agreed on 2 after discussing the above issues. We visited Jan 4 2018 for dinner (6pm).

ZG7aMS3LwVrVCQ9EKGJAAg.text: I have not left a review in years. -- Reliable French Restaurant. The service from Mr Nelson was great. His service was good as it gets. ( like we were in his home )  Peace armen

MHcbvIleEpSbRrlUUOc0ww.text: Awesome place.  Had a very helpful and friendly waiter John-Paul. He was able to personally recommend things because he has tried it himself.  I would recommend asking for him. Great experience and food. It was a little loud in the main area but I am looking forward to going back soon. Fresh warm baguette in a bag with salted butter yum.

JbNdQWYbBwFTE2QA9HxliA.text: I truly wish I could give half stars sometimes. This restaurant really did come in between a 3 and a 4 for me. I went here during a work conference trip with some coworkers when we were trying to escape yet another vendor dinner. The decor is absolutely beautiful and definitely makes you feel like you are in the Aria. It's very French classic. That part of it I will say, was a five star.   For food, I started with the onion soup (as did all three of my coworkers) and it was phenomenal! It was the biggest bowl of onion soup I have ever had in my life and quite possibly the tastiest. There was a ton of bread, a ton of onions, and a ton of cheese - it was everything French onion soup should be. Quite honestly, you can eat this as your meal, it was that much food. Because I had this rich soup, I decided to do a lighter dinner and had the mussels. The mussels were definitely prepared well, they had no grit or sand and they were all steamed open - for me, the miss here was simply the flavor. I also tried my coworkers gnocchi which was heavenly but a very heavy dish as well. I mean for crying out loud this is French food so richness, I guess is something that should be expected.  The service was lackluster and our server was not knowledgeable which for a restaurant of this caliber was extremely disappointing and definitely tainted the experience.  All things considered, this was a very nice restaurant and I would certainly go back to have some french onion soup if nothing else.
